The Prime Minister consulted his colleagues on a suggestion made privately to him by the archbishop of Canterbury that the Government shouldassociate itself in some way with the observance of January 3rd, the first Sunday in the New Year,as a Special Day of Prayer for the welfare of thenation. He recalled that in October, before theGeneral Election, the two Archbishops and theFederal Council of the Free Churches had publishedan appeal for continuous prayer to culminate on thefirst Sunday of the New Year. He informed theCabinet that since then he had been urged from various quarters, but not including the Archbishops,that the Government should ask the King to call aSpecial Day of Prayer. He had resisted this stiggestionmade almost immediately after the General Election,on the ground that the essential conditions of sucha day were a unanimity of response and solemnity.If a day were called so soon after the Election itwas inevitable that it would be misrepresented amonga not inconsiderable section of the community as aday of partisan thanksgiving. There could, therefore,be no certainty of securing the two essential condi-tions mentioned above. These objections were accepted at the time by those who had approached the Prime Minister. The Archbishop of Canterburynow proposed to issue something reminding the peopleof the October appeal, and suggested that Jaraary 3rdbe treated as a Special Day; he had ascertained that the King might be ready to associate himself with this to the extent of authorising His Grace tostate in his "reminder" that "The proposed observance of the day meets with the entire approbation andendorsement of His Majesty the King", The Archbishophad now invited the Prime Minister, on behalf of theGovernment, to support the appeal also in one of-1- the two following ways: either to join with him and the Free Church Leader in signing jointly aletter for publication asking for the prayers of all for the welfare of the country on the first Sundayof the New Year* or, alternatively, to send aletter for publication saying that he and hiscolleagues were mindful that the first Sunday in theNew Year was set aside as a Special Pay by theArchbishops and the heads of the Free Churches asthe culmination of the continuous prayer for which"they had appealed in the autumn; that he earnestlyhoped that all sections of the community would participate in that Day, and that his colleagues and himself would draw real encouragement therefrom.The Prime Minister pointed out that the Kingrsendorsement to the observance of the Day would notnecessarily involve Government participation, as in1915, 1916 and 1917 His Majesty authorised by directarrangement with the Archbishop the publication ofan intimation similar to that referred to above ina letter in which the Archbishop called the nation to prayer in connection with the War, There was no suggestion that His Majesty should be asked to call the nation to prayer by Proclamation, as was donein 1918.The Cabinet agreed that on the present occasionit would be better that the Government should not participate officially in any appeal which the archbishop might make that January 3rd be treatedas a Special Day of Prayer. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Chancellor of the Exchequer (C .P .-307 (31)) onthe scheme included in the Finance Act, 19 31, forthe valuation of land and the imposition of a LandValue Tax. After a detailed examination of the new factors in the situation resulting from recentfinancial, economic and political events, theChancellor of the Exchequer reached the conclusionthat it was now impracticable to defend the contin-uation of the expense of the valuation, and he proposed that the Valuation Clauses of the finance act should be suspended.The Prime Minister informed the Cabinet that hehad felt obliged to summon a Special Meeting toconsider this question, as the Chancellor of theExchequer bad to make an announcement on the subject in the House of Commons on the following afternoon.The question was discussed throughout in a spiritof earnest desire to meet the political difficultiesof those who had supported the measure in the lateParliament.The proposal of the Chancellor of the exchequer was criticised partly on matters of detail, butalso on the ground that it was contrary to theusual practice for a Government to reverse thelegislation of its predecessors. It was argued that suspension was tantamount to repeal.While it was frankly recognised that the principle involved was one which the political Partiesrepresented in the Cabinet approached from differentpoints of view, it was generally felt that as amatter of practical politics it would hardly be possible to persuade the present House of commons to continue this expenditure at a time of drasticeconomy and burdensome taxation. In this connectionattention was drawn to the opportunities that would present themselves to opponents of the measure for raising the question in Parliament as one of economy,as it involves expenditure from the Votes not only of the Department of Inland Revenue but also of theOffice of Works for rent of premises, and of theMinistry of Agriculture and Fisheries for maps.The Cabinet was reminded that in the course ofthe Parliamentary Debates on these proposals therehad been indications that the principle of anIncrement Value Duty might now be acceptable even to those who were opposed to the Land Value Tax,particularly if the Duty was imposed in connectionwith the development of town planning. It wassuggested that the political situation might be eased if the announcement of the suspension of theLand Clauses for reasons of economy were to be accompanied by a statement that the national government was exploring the question of whetherthe practical difficulties of administering anIncrement Duty (in cases where the improved valueof land is not due to the owner's efforts) couldnot be overcome, with a view to the resumption of valuation when the financial situation should permit.The Chancellor of the Exchequer informed hiscolleagues that he had already given his Departmentinstructions to examine this proposal. The general view of the Cabinet, however, was that it would notbe advisable, at the present stage, to make anannouncement on these lines, and that it would be-4-t preferable for the Chancellor of the Exchequer to announce that the scheme was to be suspended for reasons of economy.The Cabinet agreedThat the Chancellor of the Exchequer,taking into account the discussionsummarised above, should announce that for reasons of financial stringency it had been decidedto suspend the Land ValuationClauses of the Finance Act, 1931,but that this decision "was taken without reference to the merits of the scheme and did not involveits annulment.
